SENT.plain: The clinical course of 16 consecutive patients with stenosis of the middle cerebral artery angiographically diagnosed between 1970 and 1977 was reviewed
All were managed nonsurgically with medical treatment including anticoagulation
Prior to therapy, transient ischemic attacks had occurred in 15 and cerebral infarction in 11
Initially, none exhibited more than a minor neurological deficit

Follow-up from one month to six years showed a benign course in 14 patients: 13 experienced no subsequent transient attacks or new stroke; 1 had repeated transient attacks for two years but not in the following four years
Two of the 16 developed a severe stroke early in the course, before medical therapy was started
No distinctive clinical or radiographic features were identified that permitted prediction of the outcome
This small series supports the need for a randomized study of bypass efficacy in these patients
